Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Measuring the Internet during Novel Coronavirus to Evaluate Quarantine (RAPID-MINSEQ)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The world is employing social distancing, work-from-home, and study-from-home to limit COVID-19's spread until the availability of early detection and a vaccine for COVID-19. Implementation of these policies varies across the U.S. and globally due to local circumstances. A common consequence is a huge shift in Internet use, with university dormitories and high schools emptying and home use increasing. The goal of this project is to observe this shift, globally, through changes in Internet address usage, allowing observation of early reactions to COVID and, one hopes, a future shift back.<br/><br/>This project plans to develop two complementary methods of assessing Internet use by measuring address activity and how it changes relative to historical trends. The project will directly measure Internet address use globally based on continuous, ongoing measurements of more than 4 million IPv4 networks. The project will also directly measure Internet address use in network traffic at a regional Internet exchange point where multiple Internet providers interconnect. The first approach provides a global picture, while the second provides a more detailed but regional picture; together they will help evaluate measurement accuracy.<br/><br/>This project allows to capture an improved global picture of how different parts of the world react to COVID-19, as seen through their use of the Internet. In particular, the results from this research will help understand changing behavior of networks compared to historical data, and provide a new method based on address usage to characterize how people are staying home, and to look for the effectiveness and onset of work-from-home and shelter-in-place.<br/><br/>The project website will be at https://ant.isi.edu/minceq. The project will make all new data generated by this project available at no cost to researchers at https://ant.isi.edu/datasets. The project website and data will persist indefinitely; as of 2020 the website already provides five years of archival data that serves as a baseline.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MINCEQ project developed and validated automated algorithms that detect work-from-home (WFH).

The MINCEQ WFH algorithms detect changes by re-examining existing scans of the IPv4 Internet taken from Internet outage measurements (https://outage.ant.isi.edu/). The algorithms accumulate data from several scans to count how many users are active in each IPv4 block of 256 addresses. The algorithms then identify change-sensitive blocks as those that show daily patterns that, and watch these blocks of decreased use.

Figure 1a shows an example block at the University of Southern California where ground truth is available. The top graph shows 3 months of data, with 5 workday bumps in most weeks, but no bumps starting mid-March when USC began WFH. Our algorithms extract this pattern (Figure 1b) and automatically detect changes (Figure 1c).

Figure 2 shows the 420k change-sensitve blocks (each an IPv4 /24 prefix, like 192.0.2.*) seen in 2020h1. This data is taken from examination of data for 5.1M global blocks. The project found between 188k and 420k are change-sensitive.

Figure 3 shows MINCEQ data showed WFH changes in China, India, and the Philippines. The data confirmed known events and ?discovered? events that were then confirmed in public news reports. Validation shows that most network changes that are detected correspond to Covid-WFH dates (precision is 93%).

Figure 4 shows a screenshot from the MINCEQ public website to visualize Covid-WFH detections over the first 6 months of 2020. This data is browsable in our public website https://covid.ant.isi.edu. An Research-Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) project further enhanced this website by supporting ?drill-down? interaction, where clicking on a location can show a timeline of response over the 6 months, or which specific ISPs showed WFH.

Data is available to researchers on request at https://ant.isi.edu/datasets/.

The direct impact of this work has been new algorithms and a public website sharing the data, and demonstration that the Internet can provide a ?sensor? for some kinds of public behavior. One paper about the website has been published, and a paper about the algorithms is currently under peer review. The work and its data has directly supported one PhD student and one undergraduate researcher.

The broader impact is an improved global picture of how different parts of the world react to COVID-19, as seen through their use of the Internet. The visualization algorithms from this work have also been used in our website visualizing Internet outages.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: John S Heidemann

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The MINCEQ project developed and validated automated algorithms that detect work-from-home (WFH). The MINCEQ WFH algorithms detect changes by re-examining existing scans of the IPv4 Internet taken from Internet outage measurements (https://outage.ant.isi.edu/). The algorithms accumulate data from several scans to count how many users are active in each IPv4 block of 256 addresses. The algorithms then identify change-sensitive blocks as those that show daily patterns that, and watch these blocks of decreased use. Figure 1a shows an example block at the University of Southern California where ground truth is available. The top graph shows 3 months of data, with 5 workday bumps in most weeks, but no bumps starting mid-March when USC began WFH. Our algorithms extract this pattern (Figure 1b) and automatically detect changes (Figure 1c). Figure 2 shows the 420k change-sensitve blocks (each an IPv4 /24 prefix, like 192.0.2.*) seen in 2020h1. This data is taken from examination of data for 5.1M global blocks. The project found between 188k and 420k are change-sensitive. Figure 3 shows MINCEQ data showed WFH changes in China, India, and the Philippines. The data confirmed known events and ?discovered? events that were then confirmed in public news reports. Validation shows that most network changes that are detected correspond to Covid-WFH dates (precision is 93%). Figure 4 shows a screenshot from the MINCEQ public website to visualize Covid-WFH detections over the first 6 months of 2020. This data is browsable in our public website https://covid.ant.isi.edu. An Research-Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) project further enhanced this website by supporting ?drill-down? interaction, where clicking on a location can show a timeline of response over the 6 months, or which specific ISPs showed WFH. Data is available to researchers on request at https://ant.isi.edu/datasets/. The direct impact of this work has been new algorithms and a public website sharing the data, and demonstration that the Internet can provide a ?sensor? for some kinds of public behavior. One paper about the website has been published, and a paper about the algorithms is currently under peer review. The work and its data has directly supported one PhD student and one undergraduate researcher. The broader impact is an improved global picture of how different parts of the world react to COVID-19, as seen through their use of the Internet. The visualization algorithms from this work have also been used in our website visualizing Internet outages. Last Modified: 07/29/2022 Submitted by: John S Heidemann
